captions.text: Knowledge Channel

A man and woman meet
during curfew hours.
Where are they going?

The painter painted
the hearts of lovers with a brush.
A red ink-and-wash painting.

Public display of affection
around the city.

Paintings of the painter,
flying in the face of the custom.
The painter knew that

even a very conservative society cannot
control the human instincts for love.

Here are the yangban
who fell in love with women.

They set the women on horses,
and became enslaved by their passion.

A yangban politely hands
a woman a cigar.

A yangban who is wearing
a horseman's hat instead of his gat.
The horseman is at a loss.

The painter's paintings lampoon
the hypocritical yangban.

While the yangban who are obsessed with
entertainment are supporting roles,
women are leading roles.
The painter particularly favored

gisaeng, a new social class that emerged
in the late Joseon Dynasty.

Gisaeng who enjoyed free love
and had voluptuous charms
became great models for the painter.

The first bodies of women
that appeared in Korean paintings

Straightforward and sensational,
but not vulgar paintings.

Boy monks who are giggling
while peeping at the gisaeng.

Sophisticated and realistic depictions
in a scene of bathing.

A yellow jeogori and orange skirt
draw attention.

The painter's careful calculation to draw
attention with loud and showy colors.

The painter is recorded in history
with only two lines.

"Shin Yun-bok, pen name: Hyewon,
son of Shin Han-pyeong

government position: cheomsa,
He was good at genre paintings."

- Biographical dictionary
of Korean painters

The existence of painter Shin Yun-bok
who lived 200 years ago
can be proven by

the collection of Korean genre paintings,
which has 30 paintings,
and a few more paintings.

As no one has done this,
it is interesting.

As no one has done this,
it is superb."

title: EBS 클립뱅크(Clipbank) - 신윤복의 풍속화(Shin Yun-bok's Genre Paintings)
